sentences.sentence: Our prisoner’s furious( 猛烈的 ) resistance did not apparently indicate any hatred towards ourselves, for on finding himself powerless, he smiled in a friendly manner.
“If there’s a vacant place for a chief of the police, I think you are the man for it,” he said, gazing( 盯着 ) with obvious admiration at my roommate.
After arriving at the police station, an inspector joined us in the interview.
“I’ve got a good deal to say,” Jefferson said slowly.
“I want to tell you gentlemen all about it.”
“Hadn’t you better save that for your trial?” asked the inspector.
“I may never be tried,” he answered. “You needn’t look surprised. It isn’t suicide( 自杀 ) I am thinking of.
Are you a Doctor?”
He turned his fierce dark eyes upon me as he asked this last question.
“Yes. I am,” I answered.
“Then put your hand here,” he said, with a smile, pointing with his handcuffed wrists towards his chest.
I did so, and became at once conscious of what was going on inside.
“Oh,” I cried, “you have an aortic aneurysm( 主动脉瘤 )!”
“That’s what they call it,” he said.
The inspector and the two detectives had a hurried discussion about allowing him to tell his story.
“Do you consider, Doctor, that there is any immediate danger?” the former asked.
“Most certainly there is,” I answered.
“In that case it is clearly our duty, in the interests of justice, to take his statement,” said the inspector.
“I’ll sit down, with your permission,” the prisoner said, suiting the action to the word( 应声坐下 ).
“Every word I say is the absolute truth, and how you use it is a matter of no consequence( 重要性 ) to me.”
With these words, Jefferson Hope leaned( 倚靠着 ) back in his chair and began the following remarkable statement.
“It doesn’t much matter to you why I hated these men,” he said, “it’s enough that they were guilty of the death of two human beings—a father and a daughter.
Therefore, they had to pay for it with their own lives.
They were rich and I was poor, so that it was no easy matter for me to follow them.
When I got to London, my pockets were about empty, and I found that I must do something to earn my living.
Driving and riding are as natural to me as walking, so I applied at a cab company office, and soon got employment.
It was some time before I found out where my two gentlemen were living.
I asked and asked until at last I found them by chance.
They were at a boarding-house at Camberwell( 坎伯威尔，地名 ).
When once I found them out, I knew that I had them at my mercy.
I had grown my beard, and there was no chance of their recognizing me.
I was determined that they should not escape me again.
They were very near doing it, even so.
They must have thought that there was some chance of their being followed, for they would never go out alone, and never go out after nightfall( 傍晚 ).
During two weeks I drove behind them every day, and never once saw them separate.
At last, one evening I was driving up and down the street Torquay Terrace in which they stayed, when I saw a cab drive up to their door.
Presently( 一会儿 ) some luggage was brought out, and after a time Drebber and Stangerson followed it, and drove off( 驱车离去 ).
I drove my cab and kept within sight of them.
At Euston Station, they got out, and I followed them on to the platform.
I heard them ask for the Liverpool train, and the guard answer that one had just gone and there would not be another for some hours.
Stangerson seemed to be upset at that, but Drebber was rather pleased.
I got so close to them in the crowd that I could hear every word they said.
Drebber said that he had a little business of his own to take care of, and that if Stangerson would wait for him, he would soon return.
Then Stangerson said that if Drebber missed the last train, Drebber could find him at Halliday’s Private Hotel.
Drebber answered that he would be back on the platform before eleven, and made his way out of the station.
The moment for which I had waited so long had at last come. I had my enemies within my power.

question.cn: 为什么Jefferson说他不会受到审判？
question.en: Why did Jefferson say that he may never be tried?

options.cn: 因为他得了重病且濒临死亡。
options.en: Because he got a serious disease and was dying.

options.cn: 因为他的朋友会帮助他逃跑。
options.en: Because his friend would help him to escape.

options.cn: 因为他会证明自己的清白。
options.en: Because he could prove his innocence.

analysis: 从文中的描述：“I may never be tried,” he answered. “You needn’t look surprised. It isn’t suicide I am thinking of. ”并且Jefferson让Dr. Watson碰他的胸膛，Dr. Watson照做后发现他得了主动脉瘤，并随时有危险。所以他是因为得了主动脉瘤重病而可能无法挨到审判当日,故选A项。

question.cn: 为什么Jefferson决定在伦敦当一名马车夫？
question.en: Why did Jefferson decide to become a cabman in London?

options.cn: 因为他知道他的仇人都在马车公司工作。
options.en: Because he knew that his enemies were working in the cab company.

options.cn: 因为他很穷又正好驾驶技术很棒。
options.en: Because he was poor and good at driving.

analysis: 文中描述杰弗逊初到伦敦时，提到：“When I got to London, my pockets were about empty, and I found that I must do something to earn my living. Driving and riding are as natural to me as walking, so I applied at a cab company office...”说明他需要维持生计，并且自己驾驶技术很棒，所以决定当个马车夫，故选C项。

question.cn: 为什么Jefferson不在第一次见到他的仇人时就杀了他们？
question.en: Why didn’t Jefferson kill his enemies when he first saw them?

options.en: Because he didn’t take his weapon .

options.cn: 因为当他的仇人一直待在一起时，他没有一个好时机。
options.en: Because he didn’t have a good chance when his enemies always stayed together.

analysis: 文中描述Jefferson跟踪他的仇人时:“During two weeks I drove behind them every day, and never once saw them separate.”说明因为仇人一直待在一起，他找不到机会下手，故选C项。

question.cn: 为什么Stangerson和Drebber最终在火车站分开？
question.en: Why did Stangerson and Drebber finally separate at the train station?

options.cn: 因为他们不想再待在一起了。
options.en: Because they didn’t want to stay together anymore.

options.cn: 因为他们错过了火车且Drebber有其他事情要做。
options.en: Because they missed the train and Drebber had something else to do.

options.cn: 因为他们赶上了不同班次的火车。

analysis: 文中在描述他们在火车站时写到:“I heard them ask for the Liverpool train, and the guard answer that one had just gone and there would not be another for some hours...Drebber said that he had a little business of his own to take care of, and that if Stangerson would wait for him, he would soon return.”说明他们错过了火车且Drebber还有其他事情要做，所以暂时分开，故选B项。

question.cn: 根据今天的故事，Jefferson在发现他的仇人分散后会怎么做？
question.en: According to the story, what would Jefferson do when he found his enemies were separated?

options.cn: 他会跟踪他们并杀死他们。
options.en: He would follow them and kill them.
He would go back to America.
He would wait at the station.

analysis: 文中描述Jefferson跟踪仇人很久并未有任何成果。好不容易两人分散，他一定会实行自己的复仇计划，故选A项。
